comment.author: 16333811@N00
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Flickr Commons, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: The anticipated 1916 Summer Olympics, which were to be officially known as the Games of the VI Olympiad, were to have been held in Berlin, Germany. At the outbreak of World War I in 1914, organization continued as no one anticipated that the war would continue for several years. Eventually, though, the Games were canceled. Alexandria and Budapest had bid unsuccessfully for the 1916 Games. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1916_Summer_Olympics Work on the stadium began in 1912. The opening ceremony was on June 8, 1913. I will add the new information from the New York Times to Wikipedia.

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: Richard Arthur Norton:  Thank you for your information about this stadium and its relationship to the canceled 1916 Summer Olympics. We will update the description when we reload the database.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: Could somebody please tell me what a "turner" is?

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: The German word "Turner" means gymnast. The name of the Mission Turn Hall in San Francisco, built in 1910 near the time of this photo, is another example of how the German word was borrowed into English. Hope you'll enjoy some photos of that athletic club, as documented in the Historic American Buildings Survey collection, hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/hhh.ca1800

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: LOC, thank you for that explanation.  I did not think of it being a non-English word.
